title: La soja a la deriva, en un mercado convulsionado por la política global, por Manuel Alvarado Ledesma - Agrositio
content: Después de haber alcanzado un pico el 14 de mayo, el precio del aceite mantiene una clara tendencia descendente, ...
resumen: Después de haber alcanzado un pico el 14 de mayo, el precio del aceite mantiene una clara tendencia descendente, agudizada. En un ambiente convulsionado por las políticas de Trump, este lunes fue una jornada negativa en Chicago. Y no solo para la soja, también para el maíz. En este cuadro arancelario, un factor bajista determinó la tónica del día: la ausencia de noticias alentadoras en relación a los biocombustibles, especialmente al biodiésel. En el último mes, después de haber alcanzado un pico el 14 de mayo, el precio mantiene una clara tendencia descendente, agudizada en los recientes días. Como el principal insumo para la elaboración de biodiésel es el aceite de soja, todo aquello que pasa con este aceite en EE.UU. es más que relevante en el precio de la soja. El incierto conflicto comercial mantenido por este país con China ha promovido fuertes recortes en los precios FOB del poroto estadounidense, con relación al procedente de América del Sur. Para echar nafta al fuego, el viernes pasado el gobierno de Trump acusó al país asiático de "violar" el acuerdo alcanzado en Suiza que posibilitó la reducción de aranceles. Trump publicó en su red Truth Social que Pekín "ha violado totalmente su acuerdo con nosotros". Este lunes, Ministerio de Comercio chino negó la acusación al tiempo que remarcaba la responsabilidad de EE.UU. en faltar a lo pactado en Ginebra. Recordemos que ambas naciones habían acordado en abril reducir por 90 días los aranceles aplicados mutuamente, en Ginebra. La posición julio del aceite cayó US$ 13,45 y quedó con un valor de US$ 1020,28 por tonelada. Otro elemento bajista resulta de la presión ejercida por la entrada de la soja de Brasil, al circuito comercial. Se une a ello, un cuadro más alentador para la oferta, a consecuencia del mejoramiento del clima y de la interrupción de lluvias en la zona agrícola argentina, algo fundamental para continuar con la demorada cosecha de soja.

title: Industria del acero recibe otro golpe, ahora desde México
content: En días recientes, la industria del acero en México, que lleva a cabo importaciones de este tipo de mercancía, recibió otro duro golpe que se suma al de los aranceles impuestos por Trump a dicho ...
resumen: La industria del acero en México recibió otro golpe. El 5 de mayo se anunció la eliminación o desincorporación de poco más del 50% de los molinos extranjeros inscritos en el registro de la Secretaría de Economía, originarios de China, Vietnam, la India, Alemania, Brasil y Corea del Norte, entre otros países. La Secretaría de Economía publicó en el Diario Oficial de la Federación modificaciones a las Reglas y Criterios de Carácter General en Materia de Comercio Exterior, respecto a la tramitación de los Avisos Automáticos de Importación de Productos Siderúrgicos. Se requiere el registro de molinos productores de acero extranjeros. La Secretaría de Economía requiere información como nombre, propietario, tipo de molino, ubicación, georreferencia, página web y capacidad nominal de acero bruto anual en toneladas. Marcelo Ebrard indicó que detectaron inconsistencias e irregularidades en 1,062 de 2,233 molinos registrados, con fecha de corte a febrero de este año. La medida implementada por el Gobierno federal representa un fuerte golpe a diversas industrias. Las reglas no establecen las causales, infracciones o irregularidades que darán inicio al procedimiento para dar de baja a un molino. Los importadores se encuentran en un estado de incertidumbre, inseguridad e indefensión jurídica. La medida genera dudas sobre si el objetivo fue proteger la producción nacional de acero o responder a la presión de Estados Unidos para reducir la importación de acero proveniente de China.

title: Week Sixteen and Seventeen in Trade
content: Week Seventeen - CIT Unequivocally Strikes Down IEEPA Tariffs as Invalid - On May 28, 2025, a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court ...
resumen:
**Week Seventeen**

*   On May 28, 2025, a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of International Trade (CIT) held tariffs imposed by the Trump Administration pursuant to the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 (IEEPA) to be unlawful and invalid.
*   The CIT’s order covers IEEPA tariffs imposed against Canada, Mexico and China related to fentanyl trade (IEEPA Fentanyl tariffs) as well as IEEPA reciprocal tariffs of 10% imposed on imports from all trading partners (IEEPA Reciprocal tariffs).
*   The Court vacated the Executive Orders imposing the various IEEPA tariffs, including all modifications and amendments thereto and permanently enjoined their operation.
*   The CIT ordered the administration to issue necessary administrative orders within 10 calendar days to effectuate the permanent injunction.
*   The government has filed a motion to stay the CIT’s order pending the appeal which it filed before the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit (CAFC).
*   The court has ordered the plaintiffs to reply to the motion for a stay by June 2, 2025.
*   The government also filed a motion for stay with the CAFC, which has for the moment paused implementation of the CIT’s order until it considers the government’s motion.
*   The CAFC has ordered the plaintiffs to respond to the government’s motion by June 5 with the government having another opportunity to respond by June 9.
*   On May 29, 2025, US District Court for the District of Columbia in Learning Resources, Inc. et al v. Donald J. Trump et al granted a preliminary injunction staying the imposition of the IEEPA tariffs on the grounds that IEEPA does not grant tariff authority.
*   The court also held that CIT did not have jurisdiction over the case because IEEPA is not a “law of the United States providing for . . . tariffs.”
*   The case was filed by Plaintiffs Learning Resources, Inc. and hand2mind, Inc.
*   The court issued a preliminary injunction and enjoined the collection of tariffs against the two plaintiffs.
*   It also stayed operation of the preliminary injunction for 14 days.
*   The government has appealed the decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit.
*   On May 30, 2025 CBP issued CSMS Message # 65201773 updating its guidance for in-transit goods in CSMS # 64680374, “GUIDANCE – Reciprocal Tariffs, April 5 and April 9, 2025, Effective Dates”.
*   CBP has extended the May 28, 2025 date to June 16, 2025.
*   Articles of countries subject to IEEPA Reciprocal tariffs that were (1) loaded onto a vessel at the port of loading and in-transit on the final mode of transport on or after April 5, 2025, and before April 9, 2025, and (2) are entered for consumption, or withdrawn from warehouse for consumption, before June 16, 2025, are subject to the 10% additional tariff rate.
*   Products of China that are (1) loaded onto a vessel at the port of loading and in transit on the final mode of transport on or after April 9, 2025, and before April 10, 2025, and (2) are entered for consumption, or withdrawn from warehouse for consumption, before June 16, 2025, are subject to the 10% additional tariff rate.
*   On May 23, 2025, the U.S. Treasury Department’s Office of Foreign Assets Control (“OFAC”) issued Syria General License 25 (“GL 25”) in order to authorize certain transactions which would otherwise be prohibited under existing OFAC Syrian sanctions.
*   GL 25 generally authorizes U.S. persons to perform transactions with Syria provided that those transactions do not involve blocked persons listed on OFAC’s Specially Designated Nationals and Blocked Persons List (“SDN List”).
*   GL 25 authorizes U.S. persons to transact with the President Ahmed al-Sharaa regime of the Government of Syria as in existence on or after May 13, 2025.
*   GL 25 also authorizes U.S. persons to transact with specific SDNs listed on its attached Annex A as well as entities in which those SDNs directly or indirectly hold a 50 percent or greater ownership interest.
*   The SDNs listed on GL 25’s Annex A include (but are not limited to) the Commercial Bank of Syria, the Central Bank of Syria, the Syrian Petroleum Company and the Syrian Ministry of Petroleum and Mineral Resources.
*   OFAC issued a FAQ Fact Sheet on May 28, 2025 to provide additional guidance on GL 25.
*   The separate U.S. Export Administration Regulations (“EAR”) continue to impose a nearly complete prohibition on exports and reexports of all items “subject to the EAR” to Syria (subject to a narrow exception for food and medicine classified as EAR99).
*   The U.S. Commerce Department’s Bureau of Industry and Security (“BIS”) has not yet taken any action to lift the EAR’s Syria embargo or issue any sort of License Exception equivalent to OFAC’s GL 25.

**Week Sixteen**

*   On May 20, 2025, the Department of Commerce issued a Federal Register notice (“Notice”) detailing the process for car manufacturers eligible for preferential tariff treatment under the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) to determine and report the percentage of U.S.-origin content in their vehicles to qualify for reduced Section 232 tariffs.
*   The Notice specifies that once the Department of Commerce completes its review and determines the U.S.-origin content, it will inform both the importer and U.S. Customs and Border Protection of the portion of the vehicle subject to tariffs.
*   The Notice clarifies that the submission process described does not cover subsequent adjustments under the Section 232 action, which allows for customs rebates on certain imported parts used in vehicles assembled in the United States.
*   The Notice states that public comments on this process will not be accepted, as the matter falls under foreign affairs and is therefore exempt from the requirements of the Administrative Procedure Act.
*   On May 22, 2025, the Department of Commerce’s Bureau of Industry and Security (“BIS”) released a diverse list of 58 requests—covering a diverse list of steel and aluminum products ranging from forks and spoons to drones and auto parts—for new products proposed as derivatives subject to Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act on steel and aluminum products.
